div1.head: Jim to M. Paul Rockwell July 29th 1915
div1.p: Got your card and am looking forward to your letter.

One of our men is returning to the States, his three months being up, and I’m sending in this letter by him. In fact two or three additional are going, and two new ones are coming out from Paris. One is [‘Lawrence’ scratched out] Waldo Pierce, the nut that started for Europe with John Reed on a cattle ship and not liking the cattle ship jumped overboard when outside of Boston light and broke a swimming record.

The night of the 22nd we caught it for fair here in town. One man was killed and two wounded. Nine others had the damndest [sic] luck I’ve ever heard of. They were having a bit of a party in one fellow’s quarters which were in a house located at the juncture of two streets. It was the logical target of the whole town but hadn’t been touched. We had had two bombardments during the day but they hadn’t come within 100 yards of our caserne, or the house in question which is quite near by. At 8.30 the affair opened up with the simultaneous arrival of four high speed, high explosive “Marmites”. The first
hit right on the nose of a small earth retaining wall in front of the house. It blew the nine to the floor with a lot of debris to boot. The other shells hit close by. They made a jump for the cave and just as they got in a shell hit the house and blew it to pieces inside. Nothing remains intact. The coats the fellows left behind are in shreds. The first shell had killed one of the section, the nicest Frenchman in the lot, as he was passing the house on the way to the caserne. I, fortunately, had passed a few minutes before. Another French member with him was badly wounded. The fellows in the cave heard the cries and went up to help. A mother and her daughter were lying clasped in each others arms, dead, alongside of our man. Soon after a shell hit just at the edge of the pavement and cellar and blew the cave to bits. Three escapes for the nine of them is mighty fortunate I think. One was cut a bit from the first shell. The wounded French fellow looked fearfully when he came running into the caserne. An eclat had gone thru [sic] his cheeks, cutting
his tongue and another got his left arm. It has only half its bones left and may have to be cut off. I got my car and took him to the Ambulance. He couldn’t speak and I didn’t know at the time the other fellow was dead. Then at the Ambulance they gave me a wounded civil to take all the way to Nancy. When I got back things were pretty bad. They had been banging Marmites all around, and on the caserne. The crowd was in the cave and safe, but wondering what was coming next. I feel mighty sorry about Maignot. He was a fine fellow.

The Medecine Divisionaire has removed the last Ambulance from Pont a Mousson now and now we have to evacuate all the way to Dieulouard at night. We hope to get a sort of Poste de Secours started so as to obviate that night trip. Its almost impossible to make without lights. The French lieutenant in charge during Salisbury’s absence had us move our bureau from the caserne, whose range had been found. The next night, the quartier where the new bureau was located was shelled with 210 s. short. Salisbury got back to day. He’s located a fine place for the bureau. Its
in the part of town nearest to Montauville [Montreuil ?], where the postes de secours start in, and makes it much better all around. Its a regular mansion with generous grounds and fixed for fare -you - well inside. Can’t believe its true, its all so damned fine. Lieutenant Kullman, our French lieutenant has beat it ^for Dieulouard, and so I pinched his room at Salisbury’s invitation. Feel like a General of 1870 in the splendor of a commandeered chateau. I would feel as if I were going it a bit too strong were it not for the fact that we’re only a few hundred lines from the Germans and so if we can make our- selves comfortable why not. My bed’s got one of those canopy’s [sketch of canopy with round top] like that over it. Some swank — and a bath room — and old housekeeper to arrange things.

The picture of you and myself came out in the N.Y.Times with a regular speil. Did you see it? Great class to it, you old publicity agent. Now be sure and let me know what’s what after you pass the Commission, and as soon as possible, for I want to arrange my “permission”.
Got a letter from Marcelle Guerin just now saying she saw you and Kiffin at Mlle. Dubouchet’s.
Last night Germans tried to pull off a sneak out in mass grenade throwing charge. They were cut to pieces and we had only 90 wounded.
